newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - June 2.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - June 2.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- One day before key heroin trafficking suspect Li Yun-chung is due to be extradited to the United States, authorities are still in the dark over a 20 million baht bribe he allegedly paid to buy his freedom and flight to Burma. Li, or Phongsak Rojjanassakkul, was re-arrested in Rangoon in late April and sent back to Thailand on May 17. In a swift 20-minute special hearing two days later, the Criminal Court ruled in favour of Li's request for immediate extradition to the U.S. and the date was fixed for tomorrow. (THE NATION)

- A Korean businessman claims he is cheated of a shipment of ladies' garments worth 80,000 baht by a professional auction bidder working in collusion with several corrupt customs officials. The businessman, who identified himself only as Kang, says customs officers ask him to buy back his own cargo for 330,000 baht. (BANGKOK POST)

- Three more wild elephants have been found to have been poisoned and one is in a serious condition. A national park official says the three pachyderms show signs of weariness and look drowsy. It is believed that the animals might have drunk water or fruit contaminated with poisonous chemicals. (BANGKOK POST)

- Veteran property developer Rangsan Torsuwan, sidelined by legal problems for nearly four years, is making his comeback in China, with plans for a 300-billion-baht project in the booming southern city of Shenzhen. The centrepiece, he says, will be the world's tallest office tower. (BANGKOK POST)

- Developing members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) must take the time to study and understand the impact of investment on their economies before entering any multilateral agreement on investment, says Krirk-krai Jirapaet, Thai Ambassador to the WTO. Krirk-krai is also chairman of a WTO committee set up to study the relationship between trade and investment. (BANGKOK POST)

- Thailand will protest against Indonesia and Malaysia increasing their tariffs from 5 percent to 45 percent on petrochemical products, as they are on the ASEAN accelerated tariff reduction programme. Petrochemical products are on the ASEAN Free Trade Area's (AFTA) "Fast Track" tariff cut programme and Indonesia and Malaysia must reduce import duties on them to between 0-5 percent by January 1, 2000 if their old tariff rates were above 20 percent. (THE NATION)
